body: I assume so, since nothing has changed our side.

temporarily skipped here:
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3817

not resolved - still needs a bugfix.

@achieveordie, I think you wrote the test so might have a good idea on what´s going on?

@fkiraly, the bug pointed out by @TonyBagnall  is on sktime its side.
The problem resides in your build system. I would use https://python-poetry.org/. This would raise an error if you have an incompatible version of keras installed.
You should fix your external packages as you wrap them and they change all the time.
I also received warnings that "things" have changed.

Things seem to be breaking after their update. To ensure smooth sailing, we could replace `keras.optimizers` with `tf.keras.optimizers` in our import statement.

Of course, one can argue that our build should hold more specific versions as said by @RikStarmans, but I'm not sure what would be the "right" approach. On one hand, the current code enables us to catch and correct such changes while on the other we'd ensure the test suite works without fail.

We should choose the latter for releases but the case here is for dev.

> You should fix your external packages as you wrap them and they change all the time.
I also received warnings that "things" have changed.

@RikStarmans, there is a longer discussion on fixing bounds for package versions
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/1480
this has only posts by me, but I remember there being long discussions, possibly in issues referencing this or on slack.

issue.title: [MNT] adopt defensive upper version bounds on package dependencies

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
The `statsmodels` breakage has again shown us that under the current model, `sktime` is vulnerable to interface changes in other packages at version zero. See #1478.

Should we perhaps adopt a more defensive stance?

More precisely:

* upper version bounds for *all* dependencies
* at each release, we bump the upper bound to the current versions, or the highest versions that don't cause breakage
* if at a release we cannot move the upper bound to current version, we open a maintenance issue to log this

Opinions, @mloning, @aiwalter, @freddyaboulton?

issue.title: [BUG] Update `test_deep_estimator_full` to incorporate new versions of tf/keras

repository.name: sktime
